newsitem.title: USA: U.S. foreign crudes pressure domestic sour grades.
newsitem.headline: U.S. foreign crudes pressure domestic sour grades.

text.p: U.S. foreign crudes from the region are pressuring domestic sour barrels at a time when some refineries have lowered operating capacities.
Traders said problems at several Midwest refineries and autumn maintenance, coupled with Canadian and Latin American heavy crudes flowing into the U.S., added to the surplus.
News Venezuela's Amuay refinery shut down a 108,000 barrel per day catcracker for at least a week of repairs today was also expected to add to short-term availability.
Sour supplies included 360,000 barrels of Oriente offered by a trader for later November.
Oriente will now be priced against West Texas Sour rather than West Texas Intermediate, according to Petroecuador's latest sales formula.
The grade was recently heard sold at WTI minus $2.60 cif.
A cargo of heavy, sweet Argentine Mendanitos moved earlier this week at WTI minus $1.35 a barrel fob, for late Nov.
U.S. Gulf imports ballooned to 8.1 million barrels per day for the week ended Oct 18, in spite of a tight arbitrage but traders said North Sea and West African cargoes were scarce.
A major was seen exploring potential outlets for Brent in late Nov/early Dec, but no delivered numbers were heard.
In the U.S. after market, Brent intermonth Nov/Dec traded at 38 cents, and Dec/Jan at 68 cents, confirming the market's downtrend from the London session.
Dec Brent partials traded at $24.68 a barrel and $24.66, up from the London IPE close of $24.63.
